page.title: 14THE CHANGING VILLAGE
page.content: For centuries there was little change in rural life in Devon. But since the turn of the century{everything}has changed. An old resident tells of the school of four teachers and seventy children, aged four to thirteen. All pupils attended Sunday School as a matter of course. The annual school "treat" was a trip to the seaside. Families had seven or more children. Boys went to work on farms, girls to do domestic duties. The village then had shops, bakery, etc. but folk then needing large purchases would walk six km to Tiverton. The doctor was at Sil- verton, seven km. Electricity was introduced in 1950; and before mains water two or three cottages shared wells. Life is now more easy, but close friendships, contentment and homemade fun have gone, and this is regretted.
